High School Census Discloses Interesting Fact. Many Activities
Forms Still Out.

Upon the request of many of the
local newspapers, Coach Van Orman has influenced the Johns Hopkins Publicity Board to furnish the
publications desiring such information with all of the latest news pertaining to University athletics. As
a result, certain men have been appointed to report the sport news to
local papers regularly every other
day. One man has charge of track,
another of baseball, and a third of
lacrosse. It will be the duty of
these men to see that no item of
interest concerning any of the three
above sports will escape publication
in Baltimore sport sheets. Under
this new system it is hoped that due
and sufficient notice will be given
to all Hopkins contests and prospects as soon as any information is
gleaned. In the past, reports of
Hopkins activities have not been
given with any regularity and frequently news of the most important
sort has either been neglected or
slighted.
A novel stunt recently "pulled"
by the Publicity Board was the exhibition of a large banner advertising the Hopkins-Oxford lacrosse
game to tile large crowds assembled at the Lyric to witness the presentation of "If I Were King."
In a censas of the graduating
classes of all the state high school:,
taken recently by the Board, it was
found that. three-quarters of the total number of graduates this June
will be girls. This looks rather
dubious and alarming to the college mentors, but it is hoped that
the masculine element will make up
in quality what is lacked in quantity.
The Board wishes to make it
known to the student body that only
a little over half of the total number of activities record sheets have
been turned in. This information
is very important, both to the board
and to the University authorities,
and all men who have delayed in
filling out these sheets are requested to do so at once. If bianks were
not received a notice/dropped in
Box 406 will bring forth the necessary form.
FRESHMAN BASEBALL UNDER WAY

A very attractive schedule has
been arranged for the Freshman
nine, including a trip to Mercersburg, Pa. There are still a few
games pending.
No team has yet been picked to
represent '25, so all candidates have
an equal start. The Freshmen will
meet this opportunity with their
usual pep and get a large squad of
candidates out, form a good team,
and .add to the Aurels of the University.

ALUMNI LACROSSE TEAM HUMBLED
BY POWERFUL VARSITY TWELVE
Old Stars Defeated by 6-3 Score. Ed Stuart Still a Marvel at
Goal. Nine Bows to Dickinson
Utilizing automobile robes, sweaters, and any other covering
they could find to protect them from the wintry blasts which blew
across Homewood Field, a shivering but enthusiastic crowd saw
the Varsity defeat the Alumni lacrosse team in the initial game of
the season last Saturday. -When Captain Joe Zoller led his team on
the field, several thousand people were clustered in the protected
portions of the stands.
The old-timers started off with a rush, and, at first, it seemed as
if the Varsity would be swept off its feet by the more experienced
men. The 'defense, however, soon tightened, and it was not long
before the attack began a bombardment of Alumni Goalkeeper Ed
Stuart, which even he could not withstand.
In the baseball game the Black and Blue went down to defeat
before the Dickinson nine by a 5-2 score.

Dean Latane Has Out-quilled the

THURSDAY'S ASSEMBLY
Member of Southern Intercollegiate Newspaper Association:
Printed by The Read-Taylor Co., Lombard and South Sts., Baltimore, Md.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 4, 1922

FRESHMAN ATTENDANCE
It seems rather a hardship upon the members of the Freshman
Class that they be forced to attend the Spring sport games.
If the members of the Class of '25 have not as yet imbibed the
spirit and traditions of Johns Hopkins it is probable that they never
will. The Freshman of last fall now believes himself to be a fullfledged unit of the student body.
It is perfectly true that a number of the first year men have
fallen down in their obligations to the University activities since the
lifting of regulations. These same duty-dodgers will find little trouble in uncovering excuses for missing our Saturday games.
It seems to us that the better plan would be to put the class on
trial for two or three weeks, allowing it to do its own policing. Then,
if self-government fails, the older system can be resorted to.
Force, at this stage of the game, does not seem the proper thing.
Give them a chance!

PUBLIC SPEAKING AND THE COLLEGE MAN
There are but few among us who do not remember the days of
"saying pieces"; the days when, clad in our "Sunday" clothes, we
were forced to stand before a tittering class and declaim "Four score
and seven years ago," or "Rode the six hundred," or something
equally appropriate. Some of us can still recall those scared, those
unnecessary sensations which we experienced.
And, strange to say, there are some who still experience these
sensations upon speaking before an audience. Years of grammar
and preparatory school have not succeeded in erasing that unnecessary feeling. These unfortunates, and they are not few in number,
still dread a public or semi-public address and attempt to escape
such at every available opportunity.
A man in order to be a success in practically any walk of life,
must be able to address an audience.
College men are given some opportunity to develop this power
of public speaking; the opportunity, however, is given only to some
of those engaged in college activities and is correspondingly limited.
It is true that there is a course of Public Speaking at Hopkins. This
course contains but thirty undergraduates out of a total enrollment
of over 700. The course, too, is purely optional, is held but one hour
weekly, and seems to be considered a waste of time by both faculty
and student.
In order to become a professor of English, of Biology, or of
Philosophy, an instructor is required to undergo a course of specialized training, to rise to his position step by step. Should not the
course in Public Speaking be rated as high as these; should it not
have just as competent, just as experienced, instructors? Surely,
the ability to address an audience is as necessary to a business man
as is a knowledge of Philosophy.
The purpose of college is avowedly to fit a man for life. Is he
-fitted when he is not able to address an audience? An improved
course in Public Speaking, a course which would be, perhaps, required for graduation, would do a great deal towards helping the
underg-raduate to ultimate success in his life work.

Man Made Lightning
"VRANKLIN removed some of the mystery.
But only recently has science really explained
the electrical phenomena of the thunderstorm.
Dr. C. P. Steinmetz expounds this theory.
Raindrops retain on their surfaces electrical
charges, given off by the sun and other incandescent bodies. In falling, raindrops combine,
but their surfaces do not increase in proportion.
Hence, the electrical pressure grows rapidly.
Finally it reaches the limit the air can stand and
the lightning flash results.

History
Journalism
Manual and Industrial Arts
Industrial Arts
Mathematics

And now we have artificial lightning. One
million volts of electricity—approximately one
fiftieth of the voltage in a lightning flash—have
been sent successfully over a transmission line
in the General Engineering Laboratory of the
General Electric Company. This is nearly five
times the voltage ever before placed on a transmission line.

Philosophy

Much valuable knowledge of high voltage
phenomena—essential for extending long distance transmission—was acquired from these
tests. Engineers now see the potential power in
remote mountain streams serving in industries
hundreds of miles away.

School Music

Man-made lightning was the result of ungrudging and patient experimentation by the
same engineers who first sent 15,000 volts over
a long distance thirty years ago.
"Keeping everlastingly at it brings success."
It is difficult to forecast what the results of the
next thirty years may be.

Mike—I gave her a box of rouge
for her birthday.
Ike—Gee, that was a flossy present, wasn't it?
Mike—Yes, but I got it all back
when she thanked me for it.—Exchange.

NEW MEN ELECTED TO BLACK AND
BLUE JAY BOARD

At a recent meeting of the
Black and Blue Jay Board the following men were elected to the
Board: Jones, Packard, Hensel,
Middleton, Cochrane, Zoller, and
Buhrer to the Business Staff; Kelley and Dunning to the Editorial
Staff; and William Cooper to the
Art Staff.
The Board decided that the
present requirement of two pages
of ads for election to the Business
Staff was too strict, so they lowered it to fifty dollars' worth of
ads and a certain amount of work
for the circulation manager. Special work for the circulation manager may also be considered as
taking the place of procuring ads.

High School Census Discloses Interesting Fact. Many Activities
Forms Still Out.

Upon the request of many of the
local newspapers, Coach Van Orman has influenced the Johns Hopkins Publicity Board to furnish the
publications desiring such information with all of the latest news pertaining to University athletics. As
a result, certain men have been appointed to report the sport news to
local papers regularly every other
day. One man has charge of track,
another of baseball, and a third of
lacrosse. It will be the duty of
these men to see that no item of
interest concerning any of the three
above sports will escape publication
in Baltimore sport sheets. Under
this new system it is hoped that due
and sufficient notice will be given
to all Hopkins contests and prospects as soon as any information is
gleaned. In the past, reports of
Hopkins activities have not been
given with any regularity and frequently news of the most important
sort has either been neglected or
slighted.
A novel stunt recently "pulled"
by the Publicity Board was the exhibition of a large banner advertising the Hopkins-Oxford lacrosse
game to tile large crowds assembled at the Lyric to witness the presentation of "If I Were King."
In a censas of the graduating
classes of all the state high school:,
taken recently by the Board, it was
found that. three-quarters of the total number of graduates this June
will be girls. This looks rather
dubious and alarming to the college mentors, but it is hoped that
the masculine element will make up
in quality what is lacked in quantity.
The Board wishes to make it
known to the student body that only
a little over half of the total number of activities record sheets have
been turned in. This information
is very important, both to the board
and to the University authorities,
and all men who have delayed in
filling out these sheets are requested to do so at once. If bianks were
not received a notice/dropped in
Box 406 will bring forth the necessary form.
FRESHMAN BASEBALL UNDER WAY

A very attractive schedule has
been arranged for the Freshman
nine, including a trip to Mercersburg, Pa. There are still a few
games pending.
No team has yet been picked to
represent '25, so all candidates have
an equal start. The Freshmen will
meet this opportunity with their
usual pep and get a large squad of
candidates out, form a good team,
and .add to the Aurels of the University.
The following is the schedule:
Friday, March 31, at 4:30 P. M..
St. Joseph's, home.
Saturday, April 8, at 10 A. M.—
City College, home.
Wednesday, April 19—Mercersburg,.away.
Saturday, April 29, at 10 A. M.—
City College,'home.
Wednesday, May 3, at 4:30 P. M.
—Friends, home.
Wednesday, May 10, at 4:30 P.
M.—Army-Navy, home.

BY POWERFUL VARSITY TWELVE
Old Stars Defeated by 6-3 Score. Ed Stuart Still a Marvel at
Goal. Nine Bows to Dickinson
Utilizing automobile robes, sweaters, and any other covering
they could find to protect them from the wintry blasts which blew
across Homewood Field, a shivering but enthusiastic crowd saw
the Varsity defeat the Alumni lacrosse team in the initial game of
the season last Saturday. -When Captain Joe Zoller led his team on
the field, several thousand people were clustered in the protected
portions of the stands.
The old-timers started off with a rush, and, at first, it seemed as
if the Varsity would be swept off its feet by the more experienced
men. The 'defense, however, soon tightened, and it was not long
before the attack began a bombardment of Alumni Goalkeeper Ed
Stuart, which even he could not withstand.
In the baseball game the Black and Blue went down to defeat
before the Dickinson nine by a 5-2 score.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 4, 1922

FRESHMAN ATTENDANCE
It seems rather a hardship upon the members of the Freshman
Class that they be forced to attend the Spring sport games.
If the members of the Class of '25 have not as yet imbibed the
spirit and traditions of Johns Hopkins it is probable that they never
will. The Freshman of last fall now believes himself to be a fullfledged unit of the student body.
It is perfectly true that a number of the first year men have
fallen down in their obligations to the University activities since the
lifting of regulations. These same duty-dodgers will find little trouble in uncovering excuses for missing our Saturday games.
It seems to us that the better plan would be to put the class on
trial for two or three weeks, allowing it to do its own policing. Then,
if self-government fails, the older system can be resorted to.
Force, at this stage of the game, does not seem the proper thing.
Give them a chance!

PUBLIC SPEAKING AND THE COLLEGE MAN
There are but few among us who do not remember the days of
"saying pieces"; the days when, clad in our "Sunday" clothes, we
were forced to stand before a tittering class and declaim "Four score
and seven years ago," or "Rode the six hundred," or something
equally appropriate. Some of us can still recall those scared, those
unnecessary sensations which we experienced.
And, strange to say, there are some who still experience these
sensations upon speaking before an audience. Years of grammar
and preparatory school have not succeeded in erasing that unnecessary feeling. These unfortunates, and they are not few in number,
still dread a public or semi-public address and attempt to escape
such at every available opportunity.
A man in order to be a success in practically any walk of life,
must be able to address an audience.
College men are given some opportunity to develop this power
of public speaking; the opportunity, however, is given only to some
of those engaged in college activities and is correspondingly limited.
It is true that there is a course of Public Speaking at Hopkins. This
course contains but thirty undergraduates out of a total enrollment
of over 700. The course, too, is purely optional, is held but one hour
weekly, and seems to be considered a waste of time by both faculty
and student.
In order to become a professor of English, of Biology, or of
Philosophy, an instructor is required to undergo a course of specialized training, to rise to his position step by step. Should not the
course in Public Speaking be rated as high as these; should it not
have just as competent, just as experienced, instructors? Surely,
the ability to address an audience is as necessary to a business man
as is a knowledge of Philosophy.
The purpose of college is avowedly to fit a man for life. Is he
-fitted when he is not able to address an audience? An improved
course in Public Speaking, a course which would be, perhaps, required for graduation, would do a great deal towards helping the
underg-raduate to ultimate success in his life work.

Man Made Lightning
"VRANKLIN removed some of the mystery.
But only recently has science really explained
the electrical phenomena of the thunderstorm.
Dr. C. P. Steinmetz expounds this theory.
Raindrops retain on their surfaces electrical
charges, given off by the sun and other incandescent bodies. In falling, raindrops combine,
but their surfaces do not increase in proportion.
Hence, the electrical pressure grows rapidly.
Finally it reaches the limit the air can stand and
the lightning flash results.

History
Journalism
Manual and Industrial Arts
Industrial Arts
Mathematics

And now we have artificial lightning. One
million volts of electricity—approximately one
fiftieth of the voltage in a lightning flash—have
been sent successfully over a transmission line
in the General Engineering Laboratory of the
General Electric Company. This is nearly five
times the voltage ever before placed on a transmission line.

Philosophy

Much valuable knowledge of high voltage
phenomena—essential for extending long distance transmission—was acquired from these
tests. Engineers now see the potential power in
remote mountain streams serving in industries
hundreds of miles away.

School Music

Man-made lightning was the result of ungrudging and patient experimentation by the
same engineers who first sent 15,000 volts over
a long distance thirty years ago.
"Keeping everlastingly at it brings success."
It is difficult to forecast what the results of the
next thirty years may be.
